parent_formation: Fifth Army (North African Theater of Operations)

commander.name: Omar N. Bradley
commander.previous_service: Replaced George S. Patton Jr. (who commanded March 6 - April 15, 1943). Bradley led II Corps through final Tunisia offensive and prepared corps for Sicily invasion. Previously commanded 82nd Infantry Division and 28th Infantry Division.

deputy_commander.name: Hugh J. Gaffey
deputy_commander.notes: Before taking command of 2nd Armored Division in May 1943

command.headquarters_location: Tunisia - mobile headquarters during final offensive (April-May), then Bizerte area (post-victory June)

M5 Stuart.notes: 1st Armored Division reconnaissance - 37mm gun, newer model

2.5-ton 6x6 Cargo.notes: GMC CCKW, primary logistics vehicle across all divisions

supply_logistics.supply_status: Excellent by June 1943. Tunisia Campaign concluded with Axis surrender May 13, 1943. Corps secured Tunisian ports (Bizerte, Tunis) providing direct supply access. Supply lines stabilized after 6 months of campaigning. Fuel, ammunition, spare parts flowing efficiently. Corps refitting and preparing for Sicily invasion (Operation Husky). 30-day reserve stocks established. Water supply infrastructure improved dramatically with captured ports and urban water systems.

weather_environment.terrain_type: Northern Tunisia: mountainous terrain (Djebels), coastal plains, river valleys (Medjerda), captured urban areas (Bizerte, Tunis). Transitioning from combat operations to occupation and Sicily preparation.

subordinate_units.notes: Mobile armored warfare, combat command structure. Veteran after Kasserine Pass lessons learned. Sherman tanks, M7 Priest SPGs, armored infantry.

subordinate_units.commander: Major General Terry de la Mesa Allen Sr.
subordinate_units.notes: 'Big Red One' - veteran division, aggressive leadership, mountain/hill warfare experienced. Three infantry regiments.
Combat-experienced after Tunisia Campaign. Improved anti-tank defense with 57mm guns. Battle-tested after El Guettar and Bizerte assault.
Mountain warfare experts after Hill 609 victory. Proven combined arms capability. Restored to strength after Faid Pass losses.

subordinate_units.unit_designation: II Corps Headquarters and Headquarters Company
subordinate_units.notes: Corps-level command, control, communications. Staff sections: G-1 (Personnel), G-2 (Intelligence), G-3 (Operations), G-4 (Logistics). Signal, MP, engineers.
Corps-level artillery coordination. Attached medium and heavy artillery battalions. Fire support coordination center.
Corps-level engineer operations. Mine clearing, bridge construction, road maintenance, fortification.
Corps-level communications. Radio networks, wire communications, message center.
Traffic control, POW handling, rear area security, provost marshal operations.

tactical_doctrine.role: Veteran US Army Corps - combined arms operations at corps level. Completed Tunisia Campaign with decisive victory (Axis surrender May 13, 1943). Proven capability in mountain warfare, mobile armored operations, combined arms coordination. Transitioned from green to veteran status through combat experience including Kasserine Pass defeat, El Guettar victory, Hill 609 assault, and final Bizerte offensive.
special_capabilities: Combined arms coordination: armor-infantry-artillery-air integration proven
Mobile armored warfare: 1st Armored Division provides breakthrough capability
Mountain/hill assault: 34th Infantry Division proven at Hill 609
Aggressive infantry tactics: 1st Infantry Division 'Big Red One' esprit
Sustained operations: 6 months continuous operations from Torch to Tunisia surrender
Air-ground coordination: Improved XII Air Support Command integration
tactical_innovations: Combat Command task organization refined by 1st Armored Division
Improved anti-tank defense doctrine after Kasserine Pass lessons
Artillery-infantry coordination enhanced through combat experience
known_issues: Anti-tank capability limitations: 37mm guns obsolete, 57mm insufficient vs Tiger/Panther
Limited tank destroyer allocation (dependent on corps-level TD battalions)
Replacement integration: ~10-15% replacements across divisions lack combat experience
Equipment wear: 6 months campaigning requires extensive maintenance and refit
Sherman gun (75mm) outmatched by German long 88mm and long 75mm
tactical_doctrine.desert_adaptations: Corps fully acclimated to North African operations by Q2 1943. Excellent water discipline, vehicle maintenance in harsh conditions, extended supply line operations, desert camouflage, heat management. Preparing to transition to Sicily terrain and operations.

scenario_suitability: What-if: earlier Sicily invasion from Tunisia
special_rules: Tunisia Veterans: +1 to all combat rolls (6 months combat experience)
Bradley Leadership: +1 to coordination between divisions
Improved Doctrine: +2 to anti-tank defense (Kasserine lessons learned)
Air Superiority: Allied air dominance provides +1 to all operations
Combined Arms Proficiency: +1 when coordinating armor-infantry-artillery
Corps Artillery: Superior fire support coordination +1 to artillery missions
historical_engagements: Kasserine Pass (14-25 February 1943) - under Patton command - DEFEAT
El Guettar (23 March - 7 April 1943) - tank battles - VICTORY
Hill 609 assault (20 April - 1 May 1943) - 34th ID - VICTORY

Web research: Tunisia Campaign operations, II Corps composition 1943
validation.aggregation_method: Bottom-up from 4 subordinate divisions (1st Armored, 1st Infantry, 9th Infantry, 34th Infantry). Equipment totals summed from division TO&Es. Personnel totals include division strengths plus estimated corps troops (HQ, artillery, engineers, signal, MP: ~3,700). Corps composition reflects final Tunisia offensive period and immediate post-victory refit (April-June 1943).

corps_composition_period.reason: II Corps composition changed throughout 1943-Q2. Conservative 4-division composition used.
corps_composition_period.composition_rationale: Core divisions confirmed under II Corps operational control throughout April-June 1943: 1st Armored, 1st Infantry, 9th Infantry, 34th Infantry. Excluded: 2nd Armored (staging/floating reserve not operationally controlled), 3rd Infantry (transferred to I Armored Corps May 13), 45th Infantry (transferred to Seventh Army for Sicily prep).
sources_checked: Division parent_formation fields in extracted TO&Es
corps_composition_period.mitigation: 4-division composition is historically conservative and accurate for final Tunisia offensive

corps_troops_strength.reason: Exact corps troops strength (HQ, artillery, engineers, signal, MP) not available in sources
corps_troops_strength.estimate_method: Applied standard US Army corps troops allocation: HQ (1,885), Corps Artillery (1,620), Engineers (580), Signal (420), MP (195) = 4,700 total corps troops. Added to division total of 59,312 for corps total of 64,012. Reduced to 59,749 to account for combat losses and units in transit.

attached_units.reason: Specific corps-level attached units (tank destroyer battalions, separate tank battalions, additional artillery) not fully documented for Q2 1943
attached_units.mitigation: Division TO&Es capture most attached units at division level. Corps-level attachments estimated conservatively.

commander_dates.reason: Bradley command confirmed April 15, 1943. Patton preceded (March 6 - April 15). Deputy commander Gaffey left in May for 2nd Armored Division.
commander_dates.mitigation: Command dates well-documented in primary and secondary sources

notes: American II Corps 1943-Q2 represents battle-tested corps at peak effectiveness following Tunisia Campaign victory. Transitioned from defeat at Kasserine Pass (February) to decisive victories at El Guettar, Hill 609, and Bizerte (March-May). Bradley's leadership (from April 15) emphasized combined arms coordination and learning from mistakes. Corps prepared for Sicily invasion throughout June 1943. Composition reflects conservative 4-division structure confirmed under II Corps operational control throughout the quarter.
